BEER WITHOUT BOUNDARIES

With a restless spirit, our brewers are always experimenting and creating bold new beers that break from the ordinary but nod to tradition.

SHOP ONLINE
Available Year Round!

CORE BEERS

Shop Now
Get 'Em Before They're Gone!

Small Batch

Shop Now
Get Outfitted

Merchandise

BROWSE GEAR
Non-Alcoholic

AKWA Botanical Water

Get Refreshed

NEW AT SPEARHEAD

There's always something going on at Spearhead Brewing Company. Here are some of the latest things you need to know!

Czech Pilsner is Back

Czech Pilsner is Back

It's that time of year again! Our authentic Czech Pilsner is back on the shelves for a limited time.
ORDER NOW
Spearhead Acquires Sweetgrass

Spearhead Acquires Sweetgrass

We have another beer in the LCBO with our recent acquisition of Sweetgrass Golden Ale!
SHOP SWEETGRASS GOLDEN ALE
Queen of Wheat Wins Beer of the Year!

Queen of Wheat Wins Beer of the Year!

We took home the coveted Beer of the Year Award at the Canadian Brewers Choice Awards!
SHOP QUEEN OF WHEAT

CORE BEERS

The mainstays of our brewery, find these beers year-round at the LCBO, the Beer Store, Grocery Stores, Convenience Stores, and in Bars and Restaurants.

WE'RE ON A QUEST

To blaze new trails and expand the domain of craft beer into brand new territory. We exist to help beer drinkers broaden their horizons and be more adventurous.
LEARN MORE

Our Taproom

Live in Kingston or passing through? Why not pop into our taproom to sample our beer and our famous atmosphere. If you're here in the summer you can kick back on our award-winning patio! We can't wait to see you in person.

TAPROOM & RETAIL HOURS
Sunday - Tuesday: 12pm - 7pm
Wednesday - Saturday: 12pm - 10pm

LOCAL DELIVERY HOURS
Monday- Friday: 4PM-9PM

Experience the Taproom

AWARDS WE'VE WON

What You're Saying

Amazing patio and beer. The food truck was amazing. My amazing cat was so angry we didn’t take him. Grade: amazing!

Tim Barber

Great brewery. Went on Aug 28th first time. Great patio, service was amazing, loved our beers, music was great. Left with beers, glasses, t-shirts, definitely will be a stop when we visit Kingston

Elaine Fish

Great beer, staff and atmosphere. My family and I always have our private events here because of how wonderful everyone is to work with. Thank you spearhead for always being awesome to us!

Ida Pourshian

FIND OUR BEER!

We're available in LCBOs, Beer Stores, Bars, Restaurants, Convenience Stores, Retail Stores and Grocery Stores acrosss Ontario. Pop your address in below and find out how close you are to a Spearhead Beer!

\n Analyze the overall SEO qualit.analysis:
SEO Quality Analysis

The provided HTML content demonstrates several good practices and areas that need improvement for enhanced SEO performance. The analysis includes aspects like metadata, loading optimizations, and directives for search engines.

  • Metadata: The missing <title> tag is a crucial element for SEO as it defines the title of the webpage. It is also missing meta tags for description and keywords, which are important for search engine rankings.
  • Preloading and Preconnecting: The content includes several preloading and preconnecting directives, which can help with page speed by loading resources early. This is positive for user experience and SEO.
  • Google Tag Manager: Including scripts like Google Tag Manager is beneficial for tracking and analytics, which can indirectly contribute to SEO goals.
  • Robots.txt: The robots.txt file has been well-configured to restrict access to various parts of the site, which can help in managing which parts of the site should be crawled and indexed by search engines.
  • Sitemap: The existence of a sitemap is another positive aspect for SEO, as it helps search engines index the site more effectively.
  • Charset and Compatibility: Properly set charset and HTTP equivalents for IE compatibility ensure the page renders correctly across different devices and browsers.

Overall, the basic elements of a good SEO strategy are present, but there are areas for improvement, especially in metadata, which is crucial for search engine indexing and ranking.

\n Identify the keywords that thi.analysis:
Keyword Optimization Analysis

The given HTML content and associated files indicate the presence of a Shopify-based eCommerce site. Below is the breakdown of the keywords identified and their frequency.

Keyword Frequency
spearheadbeer 9
collections 15
checkout 9
orders 7
Disallow 30
  • The keyword spearheadbeer appears 9 times, primarily as URLs in the HTML content.
  • The keyword collections is mentioned 15 times, most likely in the robots.txt file setting disallow rules for various ecommerce URLs.
  • The keyword checkout is found 9 times, indicating restrictions around the checkout process.
  • The term orders is present 7 times, again in the context of disallow rules for the orders page.
  • The keyword Disallow appears 30 times, predominantly due to the extensive robots.txt file allowing fine control over web crawling.

Overall, the site seems to focus on managing various Shopify features and is highly restrictive in terms of which URLs are available for crawling. Actual product-oriented keywords like specific beer names or related phrases seem to be missing in the provided content.

\n Evaluate the mobile-friendline.analysis:
Mobile-Friendliness Analysis

Mobile-friendliness is crucial for modern websites as an increasing number of users access the internet via mobile devices. Here's an analysis of the provided HTML content for mobile-friendliness.

  • Viewport Meta Tag: Missing. A viewport meta tag is essential for responsive design.
  • Responsive CSS: The content includes links to various CSS files that may contain responsive styles, but without seeing the styles themselves, it's not possible to confirm.
  • Preloading Resources: The use of rel="preload" on stylesheets and fonts helps in optimizing loading times which contributes positively to mobile-friendliness.
  • Images: Favicons are included in multiple sizes, which is good practice for different device resolutions.
  • JavaScript: The use of asynchronous loading for scripts is not visible, but ensuring non-blocking scripts enhances user experience on mobile devices.
  • HTML Structure: The HTML structure itself appears simple which is good for mobile performance, but the lack of content and tested styles limits a full analysis.

Overall, the content contains several elements aimed at improving performance, but the critical viewport meta tag is missing and the responsiveness of CSS styles cannot be evaluated from the provided HTML alone.

\n Assess the page load speed bas.analysis:
Page Load Speed Analysis

The load speed of a webpage is critical for user experience and impacts SEO significantly. Based on the provided HTML content, here are several factors influencing the page load speed:

  • Preconnection and Preloading: The HTML includes multiple <link rel="preconnect"> and <link rel="preload"> elements. This is advantageous as it can reduce the initial connection time and speed up resource loading. However, overuse without prioritization can cause more harm than good.
  • Deferred Stylesheet Loading: The onload="this.onload=null;this.rel='stylesheet'" attribute in stylesheet links ensures that critical CSS is loaded first, which is beneficial for page speed.
  • External Resources: The page is loading several external resources (e.g., from cdn.shopify.com). While CDNs generally improve load times, they can introduce dependencies on external servers' performance.
  • Fonts: Webfonts are being preloaded from external sources. Custom fonts can impact load time if not properly managed.
  • Favicon Loading: Multiple favicon links are present, which could be optimized by including only necessary sizes and combining actions where possible.
  • Meta Tags and Scripts: The upfront use of meta tags for verification and scripts for tracking can slightly delay the initial loading phase. Efficiently managing and deferring non-essential scripts can help improve load times.

Overall, while some optimizations are already in place, there are further opportunities to enhance the page load speed.

\n Analyze the use and quality of.analysis:
Meta Tags Analysis

The given HTML content makes good use of various meta tags essential for search engine optimization (SEO) and improving user experience. However, there are some areas that can be enhanced for better results.

  • <meta content="tsn0LL2ZPE1r9vBcLraiRcXGi-dNGAgWXQi1dklCwPA" name="google-site-verification"/> - This tag verifies site ownership with Google, useful for accessing various Google services. This is correctly implemented.
  • <meta charset="utf-8"/> - This ensures the page uses UTF-8 character encoding, which is a good practice for broader compatibility. This is correctly implemented.
  • <meta content="IE=edge" http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible"/> - This meta tag ensures compatibility with Internet Explorer. However, this is somewhat seen as outdated and may not be necessary.
  • Missing <meta name="description" content="..."/> - A description meta tag is critical for informing search engines about the content of your page and for better click-through rates from search results. This is missing and should be included.
  • Missing <meta name="keywords" content="..."/> - While not heavily weighted by search engines today, it can still contribute to better SEO. This is missing and should be included.
  • Missing <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1"/> - This tag is crucial for making the site mobile-friendly by setting the viewport to the device's width. This is missing and should be included.

Overall, the site is leveraging some important meta tags but missing a few key ones that can significantly impact SEO and user experience.

\n Evaluate the structure and use.analysis:
Header Tag Structure and Usage Analysis

Based on the provided HTML content, the structure and use of header tags (H1, H2, H3, etc.) are crucial for both user experience and SEO. Proper use of these tags helps in organizing content hierarchically, making it easier for search engines to understand the page's structure and context. Below is an analysis of the current header tag usage:

  • H1 Tag: The <H1> tag is ideally used for the main heading of the page and should only be used once per page. However, no <H1> tag was found in the provided HTML, which is a significant oversight.
  • H2 Tags: Similarly, <H2> tags should be used for the main sections under the <H1> tag. There are no <H2> tags identified, indicating a lack of structured sub-sections.
  • H3 Tags: The <H3> tags are used for sub-sections within <H2> sections. Again, no <H3> tags are found.
  • Other Header Tags: No other header tags (<H2>, <H3>, etc.) were found either.
  • Overall Structure: The lack of header tags suggests that the document is not structured hierarchically, which can negatively impact both usability and SEO. Header tags are essential for breaking up content, providing a clear structure, and helping search engines understand the topics covered on the page.
  • Recommendation: Incorporate relevant header tags to break down the content properly. Use <H1> for the main title, <H2> for major sections, and <H3> for subsections under each <H2>. Ensure each header tag is descriptive and relevant to the section it describes.

\n Analyze the internal and exter.analysis:
Internal and External Linking Strategy Analysis

Here is an analysis of the internal and external linking strategy utilized within the provided HTML content.

  • Internal Linking: The provided HTML appears to lack visible internal links within the body content. Internal links are vital for guiding users through your site and distributing page authority. The robots.txt file suggests pagination and filtered collection pages are disallowed, which may prevent certain pages from being indexed. For an ecommerce website, it is essential to have a well-structured internal linking strategy to connect product pages, categories, and blog content.
  • External Linking: The content contains several external links to resources such as Shopify, Google Tag Manager, and CDNs for fonts and stylesheets. These are correctly implemented, utilizing HTTPS for secure connections. There is a good practice of using ‘preconnect’ and ‘preload’ to enhance performance.
  • Robots.txt and Sitemap.xml: The robots.txt and sitemap.xml files are correctly implemented and provide clear instructions for search engine crawlers. However, be cautious about disallowing pages that might be important for SEO, and ensure essential pages are included and well-linked.

\n Analyze the optimization of im.analysis:
Image Optimization Analysis

  • Missing Alt Text: Some images in your HTML content are missing alt text. Ensure that all images include descriptive alt attributes for better SEO and accessibility.
  • Alt Text Quality: Evaluate the quality of your current alt text to make sure it accurately describes the content of the images, using relevant keywords where appropriate.
  • Image Formats: Consider using modern image formats like WebP for better loading times and reduced file sizes.
  • Lazy Loading: Utilize lazy loading for images to improve your site’s loading performance, especially for pages with many images.
  • Responsive Images: Implement responsive images using the <picture> element or <img srcset="..."> attribute to deliver appropriate sizes for different devices.

In summary, optimizing images by adding descriptive alt text, using modern formats, and implementing lazy loading will significantly enhance your site's SEO and performance.

\n Evaluate the content quality a.analysis:
Content Quality and Relevance Analysis

  • Target Audience Relevance: The content includes meta tags and sitemap which are crucial for SEO but does not provide any textual content directed towards users.
    Score: 4/10
  • Content Optimization: The HTML content is more focused on structure and preloading resources rather than actual page content. There's no visible text/content for the audience.
    Score: 3/10
  • Visual Elements: The presence of favicon and preloaded stylesheets enhances user experience indirectly but lacks direct engagement.
    Score: 5/10
  • Meta Information: Good use of meta tags and Google site verification which helps with SEO but doesn't add value to content quality for end users.
    Score: 6/10
  • Robots.txt and Sitemap.xml: Well-configured for search engine crawlers which is beneficial for technical SEO but again, doesn't contribute to user-centric content.
    Score: 7/10

\n Analyze the use of schema mark.analysis:
Schema Markup and Structured Data Analysis

The following analysis details the use of schema markup and structured data within the provided HTML content:

  • No instances of schema.org structured data were detected in the provided HTML content.
  • Utilization of structured data can improve search engine understanding of the content, which might currently be missed.
  • Recommendations:
    • Implement JSON-LD format for structured data as recommended by major search engines like Google.
    • Use schema types that best represent the site contents, e.g., <script type="application/ld+json">{"@context": "https://schema.org", "@type": "Organization", "name": "Spearhead Beer"}</script>.
    • Enhance visibility for products, reviews, events, and other relevant items using appropriate schema types such as Product, Review, Event, etc.
    • Ensure all structural data is correctly implemented and validates using tools like Google's Structured Data Testing Tool.

\n Evaluate the overall user expe.analysis:
Overall User Experience Analysis

  • Good:
    • Proper use of <meta> tags for setting charset and content compatibility ensures consistency across different browsers.
    • Preloading fonts and CSS helps in improving the loading performance of the webpage.
    • Usage of favicons ensures the website has an identifiable tab icon, enhancing the user experience.
    • Structured robots.txt file to manage and control crawler behavior, aiding in SEO.
    • Well-defined sitemap.xml helping in search engine indexing, which is crucial for SEO.
  • Bad:
    • Missing <title> tag, which is essential for SEO and providing context to the user about the content of the page.
    • Excessive use of Disallow directives in robots.txt could limit the indexing of important pages.
    • External CSS and fonts are crucial for design, but the absence of a fallback mechanism can negatively affect the user experience if these resources fail to load.

\n Analyze the presence and effec.analysis:
Analysis of Call-to-Actions (CTAs)

  • Presence of CTAs: The provided HTML content does not highlight specific call-to-actions. There is no evidence of direct and compelling CTAs such as buttons or links urging the user to take action (e.g., 'Buy Now', 'Subscribe', 'Learn More').
  • Effectiveness: Given the absence of visible CTAs in the provided content, their effectiveness cannot be determined. Effective CTAs are generally prominently placed, easy to understand, and encourage immediate user interaction.
  • Recommendations:
    • Add clear and prominent CTAs throughout your content. Examples include 'Shop Now', 'Get Started', or 'Contact Us'.
    • Ensure CTAs stand out visually using contrasting colors and strategic placement.
    • Use actionable and concise language to clearly communicate the intended action.
  • Score: Due to the absence of CTAs in the provided content, the score is relatively low.

\n Check the presence and configu.analysis:
Analysis of robots.txt and sitemap.xml

  • Presence of robots.txt: The robots.txt file is present and correctly configured.
  • User-Agent Directives:
    • User-agent directives are well-defined for various bots including a general wildcard (*) for all bots.
    • Specific rules are set for Google adsbot, Nutch, and AhrefsBot.
  • Disallowed Paths:
    • Common sensitive paths such as /admin, /cart, /orders, /checkout, /account, and others are disallowed, enhancing security.
    • The directives are detailed and cover a wide range of potential paths to disallow.
  • Sitemap Declaration: The sitemap is properly declared at the end of the robots.txt file with a correct URL.
  • Presence of sitemap.xml: The sitemap.xml file is present and correctly nested.
  • Sitemap Index:
    • The sitemap index file organizes sub-sitemaps for products, pages, collections, and blogs efficiently.
    • The paths in sitemap URLs appear to be accurate and well-formed.
  • Overall Configuration: Both the robots.txt and sitemap.xml files are well-configured, enhancing the site's SEO and crawlability.
